info.game_comments:
2001 Tournament of Champions semifinal game 1.

(Sarah: You'll be glued to the screen today on the Jeopardy! Tournament of Champions.)

double_jeopardy_round: OPERA HAS BEEN VERDI, VERDI GOOD TO ME

(1, 1).clue: In the 1750s naval surgeon James Lind showed that this could be cured & prevented by eating citrus fruit

(2, 1).clue: In 1999 this city's Colts won 10 more games than in 1998, the biggest one-season improvement to date

(3, 1).clue: In 1960 this acting legend & Freemason played another Freemason, Davy Crockett, in "The Alamo"

(4, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew wears an interesting headpiece.)  Health regulations often call for some restaurant employees to wear these on their heads

(5, 1).clue: This Chinese dynasty that reigned from 1368 to 1644 was known for beautiful vases

(6, 1).clue: This kind of person doesn't deny that God exists, he just believes it's impossible to know

(1, 2).clue: He developed the live-attenuated vaccine for polio, which is given orally & requires no booster shot

(2, 2).clue: Until 1989 this was the only head coach the Dallas Cowboys ever had

(3, 2).clue: This American conjurer, escapologist & Freemason was born in Budapest in 1874 as Ehrich Weiss

(4, 2).clue: It can mean to wash shampoo off hair, or a solution to color hair

(5, 2).clue: Damien Hirst is known for his dead-animals-in-tanks artworks, notably a tiger one of these fish in formaldehyde

(6, 2).clue: This ancient medical oath begins, "I swear by Apollo physician..."

(1, 3).clue: Neatness doesn't always count -- a moldy petri dish of Staphylococcus bacteria led to the discovery of this antibiotic

(2, 3).clue: 2 of the 3 cities that had been home to the team now called the Titans

(3, 3).clue: He regularly attended Masonic lodge meetings until 1911 when he became England's First Lord of the Admiralty

(4, 3).clue: In this process, a stone surface is cleaned with tiny grains fired at high velocity

(5, 3).clue: "Lobster Trap and Fish Tail" is one of this artist's best-known mobiles

(6, 3).clue: This term for a reckless or foolish person is from the Latin for "moon-struck"

(1, 4).clue: Neatness does count -- his discovery of antiseptics reduced deaths from surgical infections

(2, 4).clue: This Dolphins quarterback retired after the 1999 season with a record 420 career touchdown passes

(3, 4).clue: This Austrian Freemason used references to Masonry in his "Magic Flute"

(4, 4).clue: It's the car care product whose symbol is seen here

(5, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew works on a craft.)  From the French meaning "to cut out", it's the decorative art I'm demonstrating here

(6, 4).clue: A synonym for rural, it can also mean simple or artless

(1, 5).clue: Interferon alone or combined with the antiviral drug Ribavirin is used to treat the C-type of this disease

(2, 5).clue: In 1967 this Green Bay Packers quarterback was named MVP of the first Super Bowl

(3, 5).clue: This former VP & Freemason launched a conspiracy to take over the U.S. Southwest

(4, 5).clue: Andy Warhol gave this steel wool product free publicity by sculpting its boxes

(5, 5).clue: Christianity & Aztec ritual inspired the thorn necklace worn by this Latina woman in a masochistic 1940 self-portrait

(6, 5).clue: It's the principal Christian church in Egypt

(1, 1).clue: The Limpopo River also has the name of this reptile that some want to make into "coil decor"

(2, 1).clue: Sergei's film about one of these labor events juxtaposed shots of workers with slaughterhouse footage

(3, 1).clue: In the 1830s Verdi studied with Vincenzo Lavigna, formerly maestro al cembalo at this Milan opera house

(4, 1).clue: In "An Hour Before Daylight" this former president shares memories of growing up in rural Georgia

(5, 1).clue: Napoleon's forces suffered about 40,000 casualties losing this June 18, 1815 battle

(6, 1).clue: After the robin goes bob-bob-bobbing along, it lays an egg of this color

(1, 2).clue: Though Botswana has little or no gold, these mineral products might get the "Midas nod"

(2, 2).clue: Sergei ran afoul of Stalin while making a film on the life & times of this brutal czar

(3, 2).clue: In English "Il Trovatore" means this, a wandering minstrel

(4, 2).clue: This anthropologist told about her early years in 1972's "Blackberry Winter"

(5, 2).clue: In May 1940 Germany attacked France through this country, now home to NATO HQ; France fell by June

(6, 2).clue: A pound of this egg delicacy from Russia could set you back $1,200; from Iran, over $1,600

(1, 3).clue: In this area that covers much of Botswana, you might take "a rash ideal trek"

(2, 3).clue: Beatrice Vitoldi played "Mother with Baby Carriage" in this film

(3, 3).clue: The title character of this Verdi opera is a hunchbacked court jester

(4, 3).clue: Title of Billie Holiday's 1965 autobiography & of the movie it later inspired

(5, 3).clue: The Third Republic began after France lost the war to this Bismarck-led German state

(6, 3).clue: The Sauropod, a dinosaur the size of a bus, came from eggs discovered in this country's Patagonia region

(1, 4).clue: If you lose all your clothes in this capital, just "go on bare"

(2, 4).clue: The title month "October" is the one in this revolutionary year

(3, 4).clue: Egyptologist Auguste Mariette claimed his scenario was the basis for the libretto of this 1871 opera

(4, 4).clue: Read up on this longtime speaker of the House in his 1987 memoir "Man of the House"

(5, 4).clue: The English won most of the battles in this 1337-1453 war but in the end France drove them out

(6, 4).clue: Chinese cooking has extremes of Egg Foo Yung & this dish of duck eggs that have been buried for a long while

(1, 5).clue: When Botswana was this British protectorate, it was perhaps more of a "can and ale hub"

(2, 5).clue: Sponsored by Upton Sinclair, Eisenstein set out to film "Que Viva" this country

(3, 5).clue: Verdi's last opera, this comic masterpiece is based in part on Shakespeare's "King Henry IV"

(4, 5).clue: This TV news producer tells his own story in "Tell Me a Story: Fifty Years & 60 Minutes in Television"

(5, 5).clue: The 1520s weren't good for France either; it lost Milan to Charles V, leader of this "empire" that began in 962

(6, 5).clue: The Franklin Mint has the eggs named for this artisan ranging from $37.50 to the eggs-pensive $6,900

(0, 0).clue: Upon this nation's independence in 1903, it was "moved" from one continent to another
